questions_attributes.content: Will the owner allow you to visit where the puppies/dogs are kept?

options_attributes.feedback_text: Yes! This is the most important step in getting a dog! Visiting is the only way to know for sure what kind of place a dog is coming from.

Not so good… Visiting is the only way to know for sure what kind of place a dog is coming from. Some owners may not want people knowing where they live. Meeting in a public place can sometimes be okay, but it can also be risky!

Hmm… Visiting is the only way to know for sure what kind of place a dog is coming from. Some owners may not want people knowing where they live. Meeting in a public place can sometimes be okay, but it can also be risky!

options_attributes.o_content: In the home with the family
options_attributes.feedback_text: Good! Dogs living indoors are more likely to be well-adjusted to living in a home.
Time to walk away! You may be looking at a potential hoarding situation or puppy farm. This type of living makes all dogs more prone to health and behavior problems.

options_attributes.o_content: In a kennel, garage, or outdoors
options_attributes.feedback_text: Woah there! If you’re looking at an adult dog, why aren't they indoors? (Are they not houstrained? Too energetic? Tearing up the house?) All puppies should be raised inside a home, where they get the socialization they need.

Find out, for sure. If you’re looking at an adult dog and they don't live indoors, why not? (Are they not houstrained? Too energetic? Tearing up the house?) All puppies should be raised inside a home, where they get the socialization they need.

options_attributes.o_content: Yes, I know them personally and trust them
options_attributes.feedback_text: Excellent! This helps you really know where your dog is coming from.

options_attributes.o_content: No, but they are a friend of a friend or family member
options_attributes.feedback_text: This comes with some risks. The less you know a person, the easier it is to be scammed or have your calls/texts ignored if you are given a sick or aggressive dog.

options_attributes.o_content: No, I found them on a website such as Craigslist or Facebook
options_attributes.feedback_text: There are some great people and pets on these sites, and some that are the complete opposite. The less you know a person, the easier it is to be scammed or have your calls/texts ignored if you are given a sick or aggressive dog.

questions_attributes.content: Why is the individual giving this dog/puppy away?

options_attributes.feedback_text: This is a very “mixed bag” and it’s hard to know how risky it might be. These are often dog-loving people who don’t do health testing or really understand genetics. (Unfortunately they are sometimes money-hungry backyard breeders.) This can sometimes put pups at higher risk of behavior and health problems.
Moving can be stressful and expensive, especially with pets. Most apartments charge fees just to have a pet. As long as the individual is not lying, this is generally not a bad sign.
Behavior problems can be *very difficult* to live with, and *very difficult* to treat. Unlike what you’ve seen on TV, serious behavior problems aren’t magically “fixed” forever with training.
This is one reason people sometimes give to cover up the real reason they are getting rid of their dog. It may be completely true, and it may not.

Just how energetic is this pup?  Are they destroying things in the home? Digging up the yard? If you don’t think you can give the dog more attention than they're getting right now, it's time to look elsewhere.
Pets are expensive! This is not an uncommon reason for people to give them up. Do your best to make sure this is truly the reason they are rehoming.

questions_attributes.content: Is the individual offering a trial period before the adoption is final? (You can take the dog home for a short time to make sure it’s a good fit.)

options_attributes.feedback_text: Great! This gives you a chance to get to know the dog and not take responsibility for rehoming a dog you just met (as long as the person is being honest).
This can get sticky! If the dog isn’t a good match, *you* may end up responsible for rehoming him.
This can get sticky! If the dog isn’t a good match, *you* may end up responsible for rehoming him.

questions_attributes.content: Has the individual socialized the puppies to people, objects, and a normal home environment?

options_attributes.o_content: Yes, and they are raised in the home
options_attributes.feedback_text: Woo hoo! Puppies need good experiences (socialization) with the things they will encounter as adults. Being raised in a home is the ideal way to prepare for life as a family pet.

options_attributes.o_content: Yes, and they are not raised inside the home
options_attributes.feedback_text: This answer isn’t a great sign… Puppies need lots of good experiences (socialization) with the things they will encounter as adults. Pups raised outside of a home are more prone to fearful and aggressive behaviors as adults.

Yikes, it’s time to walk away, as hard as it might be. Puppies need lots of good experiences (socialization) with the things they will encounter as adults. Undersocialized puppies are more prone to fearful and aggressive behaviors as adults.

Puppies need good experiences (socialization) with the things they will encounter as adults. Pups raised outside of a home are more prone to fearful and aggressive behaviors. It’s worth digging to find out the answer to this.

Good! Puppies need good experiences (socialization) with the things they will encounter as adults. Being raised in a home is the ideal way to prepare for life as a family pet. If you happen to start looking at puppies, this is good to know.

questions_attributes.content: Does the individual have vet records for the puppy/dog showing it is up to date on vaccines?

options_attributes.feedback_text: Excellent! The dog should be up to date on their rabies and distemper/parvo (DHPP) vaccines. Ideally, they've also been examined by a vet within the last year.
Uh oh. This dog could have unknown health issues. They should be up to date on their rabies and distemper/parvo (DHPP) vaccines. Ideally, they should also be examined by a vet within the last year.
This dog could have unknown health issues. Find out if you can have a copy of the pet’s vet records or have permission to get records directly from the vet.

questions_attributes.content: Does the dog have any history of behavior problems such as fear, aggression, or separation anxiety?

options_attributes.feedback_text: Behavior problems can be *very difficult* to live with, and *very difficult* to treat. Unlike what you’ve seen on TV, serious behavior problems aren’t magically “fixed” forever with training.
Hooray! As long as the individual is being truthful, this is great to know. (Behavior problems are not easy to treat!)
This is an important question to ask. Behavior problems are not easy to treat, and can require lifelong training and lifestyle changes. The person might lie, but it’s worth asking!

questions_attributes.content: Are any of the following types of phrases used in the dog’s description: “outside dog”, “protective”, “needs a firm hand”, “dominant”, “good guard dog”?

options_attributes.feedback_text: Oh dear… This can mean that the dog may have some serious behavior problems. Maybe they’re called “protective” because they growl at strangers. Maybe they “need a firm hand” because they bite. Probably not something you want to start off with!
Great! These kinds of phrases can mean the dog has some serious behavior problems. (Maybe they're called “protective” because they growls at strangers.)

These kinds of phrases can mean the dog has some serious behavior problems. Maybe they're “protective” because they growl at strangers. Maybe they “need a firm hand” because they bite. Be aware of phrases that might be hiding something.

questions_attributes.content: What is the adoption fee for the individual’s dog or puppy?

options_attributes.feedback_text: Woah, is this person trying to ensure a good home for their dog or make some money? Be careful of high adoption fees. If someone is charging a large amount for young puppies, what are you paying for? AKC papers don't indicate quality. What is worth the extra dough? Pups whose parents who have health tests done!
A good sign! Generally, this is a reasonable range for somebody rehoming their own dog/puppy or accidental litter.

Be careful of high adoption fees. If someone is charging a large amount for young puppies, what are you paying for? AKC papers do not indicate quality. What is worth the extra dough? Parents who have health tests done! To see what tests your breed should have, check out [this list] (http://www.caninehealthinfo.org/breeds.html).
